block.p: The Economy

Democratic Senators on the Finance Committee agreed on tax increases and spending cuts, pushing deficit-reduction legislation one step closer to becoming law. The accord incorporates much of what President Clinton proposed and the House approved but contains significant differences, most notably a 4.3-cents-a-gallon increase in the Federal sales tax on gasoline and diesel fuel, rather than the broader tax on energy consumption that the President had sought. [ Page A1. ]
Delays in enforcing new cable television rules could cost consumers as much as $300 million, legislators said. F.C.C. commissioners were summoned to a hearing today. [ D1. ]
The Economy

Democratic Senators on the Finance Committee agreed on tax increases and spending cuts, pushing deficit-reduction legislation one step closer to becoming law. The accord incorporates much of what President Clinton proposed and the House approved but contains significant differences, most notably a 4.3-cents-a-gallon increase in the Federal sales tax on gasoline and diesel fuel, rather than the broader tax on energy consumption that the President had sought. [ Page A1. ]
Delays in enforcing new cable television rules could cost consumers as much as $300 million, legislators said. F.C.C. commissioners were summoned to a hearing today. [ D1. ]

Builders broke ground at only a modestly faster pace in May despite a reported early-spring boom in sales of new homes. The Federal Reserve said industrial production climbed two-tenths of 1 percent last month. [ D2. ] International
Changes loom among South Africa's corporate titans, with one huge company cutting blacks into a share of economic power. [ D1. ]

Japan's Mitsubishi Estate Company is hurting because of its purchase of 80 percent of the Rockefeller Group. Income from rents at Rockefeller Center does not cover payments on the mortgage, and stormier weather lies ahead. [ D1. ] Companies
Costco Wholesale and the Price Company agreed to merge in a stock swap worth more than $2 billion. The deal is the latest sign of the winnowing of the warehouse industry. [ D1. ]

The nation's top food regulator is skeptical about reports of syringes and hypodermic needles in Pepsi-Cola cans but the Federal Government still deployed hundreds of investigators to examine the company's 400 bottling plants. [ A16. ] Pepsi wins high marks for its response to the syringes found in some cans. [ D1. ]
Infinity Broadcasting agreed to buy KRTH-FM in Los Angeles for $110 million in cash from the Beasley Broadcast Group. [ D20. ]
Bank of Montreal will more actively manage Harris Bankcorp, its principal U.S. subsidiary, by naming a top executive as chief executive of Harris. [ D4. ]
Hewlett-Packard's stock was pounded after what the company called a mistaken news report from Europe. The stock ended the day at $83.625 a share, down $3.375. [ D4. ]
Ameritech designated Richard C. Notebaert as heir to William L. Weiss when the latter steps down as next May. [ D4. ]
Carlson Hospitality will build three hotels in Branson, Mo., the Ozark community that attracts millions each year. [ D5. ]
Borden's Cracker Jack celebrated its 100th anniversary with a party at a baseball game at Wrigley Field. [ D4. ] Markets
Airlines and technology stocks weighed on the market, but the Dow Jones industrial average, pushed by a burst of program trading, ended with a 19.65 point gain at 3,511.65. [ D8. ]
Donald Trump's return to the bond market may be welcomed by investors, good news for Mr. Trump's bankers. [ D16. ]

The dollar rallied to a three-month high against the mark on expectations of a reduction in German interest rates. [ D19. ] Lumber prices plunged the daily limit on the Chicago Merc. [ D19. ] Today's Columns
The White House is staking out a middle ground in trade disputes with Japan. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ]
Stocks of two companies in the student-loan business have diverged after President Clinton's proposal to have the Government lend money directly to college students. Market Place. [ D8. ]
Oxxford Clothing is planning its first advertising since World War II, undaunted by the sorry state of the men's tailored clothing business. Stephanie Strom: Advertising. [ D20. ]
